storyContent.tagHTML: Rishabhadev's Family and Kingdom

Before his renunciation of worldly life, Bhagawän Rishabhadev, or Ädinäth, was known as King Rishabh and had two wives, Sumangalä and Sunandä. With Sumangalä, he had 99 sons, of whom Bharat was the eldest, and one daughter named Brähmi. With the second wife, Sunandä, he had one son named Bähubali and a daughter named Sundari. All of them were given proper training in different arts and crafts. Bharat became a great warrior and a politician. Bähubali was tall, well built, and strong, and hence was given his name. In Sanskrit, “bähu” means arm and “bali” means mighty. Brähmi attained a very high level of literary proficiency. She developed the first known script, known as the Brähmi script. Sundari was very proficient in mathematics. After Bhagawän Rishabhadev attained omniscience, both daughters also renounced their worldly lives and became his disciples.
Division of the Kingdom and Bharat's Ambition

As a king, Rishabhadev had the responsibility of a large kingdom. At the time of his renunciation, he handed over the city of Vinitä, also known as Ayodhyä, to Bharat, and the city of Taxashilä (Potanpur according to Digambar scriptures) to Bähubali. He gave different parts of his vast kingdom to his remaining 98 sons. Bharat quickly established control over Vinita. He was an ambitious ruler and intended to become emperor of the entire nation. For this purpose, he organized a strong army and started developing different types of fighting equipment. He also possessed a miraculous wheel called Chakraratna (“Chakra” means wheel and “ratna” means precious jewel) that would never miss its target. After developing his army and weapons, he embarked upon his journey of conquest. There was hardly anyone at the time who could withstand his well-equipped army. He easily conquered all the regions around Vinitä. Then, he turned his attention towards the lands of his 98 brothers and asked them to acknowledge his superiority. They all turned to Bhagawän Rishabhadev to ask for advice. Bhagawän explained to them the importance of conquering their inner enemies (passions) and not external enemies. He also advised them on how to attain liberation, a “true kingdom.” Having realized the futility of fighting with their elder brother, the sons surrendered their territories to him, renounced worldly life, and became disciples of Bhagawän Rishabhadev.
The Challenge of Bähubali

Now, only Bähubali remained. However, he had a different vision and would not surrender. He was conscious of his right to rule the kingdom handed over to him by his father. Moreover, he had the will and capacity to fight any invader. Therefore, when he received Bharat’s request to accept a subordinate status, he refused and began preparations to fight.

Both brothers were strong, and war between the two was sure to result in large-scale bloodshed. Therefore, counselors on both sides tried to dissuade their masters from resorting to war, but neither of them would give up their ground. War seemed inevitable as the brothers brought their armies face to face on the battlefield. Everyone shuddered at the prospect of the heavy casualties that would result from the imminent war.
The Duel

The counselors then made one last effort. They explained to their masters that the main point of contention was to determine which brother was superior. Instead of assembling a large-scale war for that purpose, a fight between the two brothers would just as easily settle the issue and would avert unnecessary bloodshed. Both brothers thought this was an excellent idea and immediately agreed. The plan was to engage in a duel, and the victor would be acknowledged as the leader.

On the day of the duel, Bharat tried to beat Bähubali by using his various permissible weapons, but all his attempts to defeat Bähubali failed. Bharat contemplated on how unbearable and shameful his defeat would be. His ambition to rule the entire world was also at stake if he did not defeat his brother. He grew desperate and ignored the rules of the duel by unleashing his miracle wheel, the Chakraratna, at Bähubali. However, he had forgotten one important characteristic of the miracle weapon: it would not harm any blood relatives of the bearer. Therefore, Bähubali remained unharmed.
Bähubali's Realization and Renunciation

Bähubali became enraged by Bharat’s violation of the rules of the duel, and he thought of smashing his elder brother with his mighty fist. As he raised his hand for that purpose, the onlookers trembled at the thought of Bharat’s imminent death.

But just as he was about to unleash his wrath, a flash of insight came to him. “What am I doing?” thought Bähubali. “Have I gone mad? Am I going to kill my elder brother for the sake of some worldly possessions that my revered father willingly abandoned and which my other brothers have given up?” He shuddered at the prospect of the imminent death of Bharat, seeing the evil in killing a respected brother. At that very moment he changed his mind. Instead of lowering his hand to hit his brother, he used it to pull out his hair (as the monks do during Dikshä) as a symbol of giving up everything and renouncing the worldly life.
Bähubali's Penance and the Elephant of Ego

However, Bähubali had not lost all of his pride and ego. He realized that if he went to his father and stated his intention of renouncing the world, he would be required to bow down and be subservient to his 98 younger brothers who were senior to him in monkhood. This was unacceptable to him. Instead, Bähubali decided to seek enlightenment on his own and started meditating on the very same spot upon which he stood. He became so immersed in his meditation that he lost track of time and could not remember how long he had stood there. He was motionless for so long that plants and creepers began to grow around his feet.

A year passed with Bähubali standing in that posture of meditation, yet he did not gain enlightenment. How could he gain it without shedding his ego? At last, Bhagawän Rishabhadev sent Brähmi and Sundari to bring him to the right path. They came to the place where Bähubali was meditating. Seeing their mighty brother standing like a rock, they calmly told him, “You cannot achieve enlightenment while sitting on an elephant. You need to get off the elephant.” As their familiar voices reached Bähubali’s ears, he opened his eyes in amazement and looked around but did not find himself on an elephant. He then realized that the elephant they were referring to, was his ego. He immediately dissolved his ego and decided to go to Bhagawän Rishabhadev and was ready to bow down to his 98 younger brothers.
Bähubali Attains Omniscience

During his long penance, he had overcome all other defiling passions except ego, which still remained between him and enlightenment. Now his ego was dissolved, and humbleness prevailed in its place. Therefore, as he took the first step towards the Lord, he achieved full enlightenment and became omniscient. (By Digambar tradition, Bähubali later became the first person to attain liberation in this era. However, Shvetämbar tradition indicates that Rishabhadev’s mother, Marudevi, attained liberation first in this era.)

In memory of this event, a gigantic, 57-foot upright statue of Bähubali stands on the hill of Vindhyagiri at Shravanbelgola, near Bangalore in southern India. It is made out of a single rock of granite and was erected about 1000 years ago. Pilgrims and visitors marvel that the statue, even under the open sky, stands spotless today.
Bharat the Chakravarti and His Enlightenment

At the same time as Bähubali was carrying out his intense meditation, Bharat had become the undisputed emperor, or Chakravarti, of the world. He was the first Chakravarti of the current time cycle of Avasarpini Ärä. As a ruler, he ruled equitably and in the interest of all, and the people were happy under his administration. India was recognized as Bharatvarsha. He himself was happy in every respect and ruled for a very long time.

One day, a ring slipped off his finger while he was in his dressing room. He noticed that the finger looked rather odd without the ring. His curiosity overtook him, and he removed all his rings. Seeing that his fingers were no longer beautiful, he took off his crown and other ornaments decorating his body and looked in the mirror. He realized that he did not look as handsome as he used to look.

This set off a train of thoughts. “I consider myself handsome and strong, but this entire look is merely due to the ornaments which do not belong to the body. The body itself is made up of blood and bones. Then why am I so attached to my body?” He thought further. “My body will not last forever and will decompose sooner or later. At that stage, I will have to leave everything behind. The only everlasting entity is the soul.” He realized that nothing in the world, including his body, really belonged to him, and soon came to a major decision. “Why not detach from all of the temporary things in life and instead focus on something that lasts forever like my father did?” Thus, he developed an acute detachment for the worldly life. As per Shvetämbar tradition, this reflection led to the rise of true enlightenment from within. As a result, he attained omniscience, or Keval-jnän, in that very room as a lay person. According to Digambar tradition, after he attained an acute detachment of worldly life, he renounced that life and became a monk, immediately achieving Keval-jnän. At the end of his life, he attained liberation.
Moral

The focus of this great story is on ego and self-realization. Ego and pride build negative karma and lead one to destructive behavior as detailed in the story. Ego also causes anger and leads one to irrational behavior. Ego and superficial pride must be overcome on the path to enlightenment and omniscience. We should all strive for cultivating humility, one of the fundamental principles of Jainism.
Highlights

• Bharat as Chakravarti. • Bharat and Bähubali’s duel and Bähubali’s realization not to harm an elder brother over material possessions. • Bähubali’s “elephant” or ego. • Bharat’s attainment of Keval-jnän.

events.title: Rishabhadev's Family
events.description: Bhagawän Rishabhadev has two wives, Sumangalä and Sunandä. Sumangalä is the mother of Bharat (eldest of 99 sons) and Brähmi. Sunandä is the mother of Bähubali and Sundari.

events.title: Early Education and Skills
events.description: All children receive training in arts and crafts. Brähmi develops the Brähmi script, and Sundari becomes proficient in mathematics.

timelineData.era: Division of Kingdom and Bharat's Ambition

events.title: Rishabhadev Renounces
events.description: Bhagawän Rishabhadev renounces worldly life and divides his kingdom.

events.title: Kingdom Divided
events.description: Ayodhyä (Vinitä) is given to Bharat, and Taxashilä (Potanpur) to Bähubali. Other sons also receive territories.

events.title: Bharat's Imperial Ambitions
events.description: Bharat aims to become emperor (Chakravarti), builds a strong army, and possesses the Chakraratna.

events.title: Conquest and Submission of Brothers
events.description: Bharat conquers surrounding regions. His 98 brothers, advised by Rishabhadev on inner conquest, renounce their territories and become disciples.

events.title: Bähubali's Defiance
events.description: Bähubali refuses to accept Bharat's subordinate status and prepares for war.

events.title: Proposal of a Duel
events.description: To avoid large-scale bloodshed, counselors suggest a duel between the brothers to determine superiority.

events.title: Bharat's Failed Attempts and Chakraratna
events.description: Bharat fails to defeat Bähubali with conventional weapons and unleashes the Chakraratna, which does not harm Bähubali due to their blood relation.

events.title: Bähubali's Moment of Insight
events.description: Enraged by Bharat's actions, Bähubali is about to strike but has a sudden realization about the futility of worldly possessions and harming his brother.

events.title: Renunciation on the Battlefield
events.description: Bähubali renounces worldly life by pulling out his hair (Panchmushthi loch).

events.title: The Obstacle of Ego
events.description: Bähubali begins meditating alone, his pride preventing him from bowing to his younger brothers who were senior in monkhood.

events.title: Year-Long Meditation
events.description: Bähubali meditates motionless for one year, with plants and creepers growing around him, but does not attain enlightenment due to his ego.

events.title: Guidance from Sisters
events.description: Brähmi and Sundari advise Bähubali that he cannot achieve enlightenment "while sitting on an elephant" (his ego).

events.title: Attainment of Omniscience
events.description: Bähubali dissolves his ego and, as he takes the first step to go to Rishabhadev, attains Keval-jnän (omniscience). Statue at Shravanbelgola commemorates him.

events.title: Bharat the Chakravarti
events.description: Bharat becomes the undisputed emperor, the first Chakravarti of the current Avasarpini Ärä. India is recognized as Bharatvarsha.

events.title: The Ring Incident and Reflection
events.description: A ring slipping from Bharat's finger leads him to reflect on the impermanence of physical beauty and worldly possessions.

events.title: Bharat Attains Omniscience
events.description: Through deep reflection, Bharat develops detachment and attains Keval-jnän. (Traditions differ: Shvetämbar - as a layperson; Digambar - after becoming a monk).

events.title: Liberation of Bharat
events.description: At the end of his life, Bharat attains liberation.

charactersData.name: Bhagawän Rishabhadev (Ädinäth)
charactersData.description: The first Tirthankar, father of Bharat and Bähubali. He renounced his kingdom and showed the path to liberation.

charactersData.name: Bharat
charactersData.description: Eldest son of Rishabhadev (by Sumangalä). An ambitious ruler who became the first Chakravarti. He later attained Keval-jnän.

charactersData.name: Bähubali
charactersData.description: Son of Rishabhadev (by Sunandä). A mighty warrior who initially clashed with Bharat but later renounced worldly life and attained Keval-jnän after overcoming his ego.

charactersData.name: Sumangalä
charactersData.description: One of King Rishabh's wives, mother of Bharat and 98 other sons, and daughter Brähmi.

charactersData.name: Sunandä
charactersData.description: One of King Rishabh's wives, mother of Bähubali and daughter Sundari.

charactersData.name: Brähmi
charactersData.description: Daughter of Rishabhadev and Sumangalä, known for her literary proficiency and developing the Brähmi script. She became a disciple of Rishabhadev.

charactersData.name: Sundari
charactersData.description: Daughter of Rishabhadev and Sunandä, proficient in mathematics. She also became a disciple of Rishabhadev.

quizData.question: Who were the parents of Bharat and Bähubali?
quizData.answer: Bhagawän Rishabhadev was their father. Bharat's mother was Sumangalä, and Bähubali's mother was Sunandä.

quizData.question: What script is Brähmi credited with developing?
What miraculous weapon did Bharat possess?
Why did the Chakraratna not harm Bähubali?
quizData.answer: Because it would not harm any blood relatives of the bearer.

quizData.question: What did Bähubali do when he realized he was about to harm his elder brother Bharat?
quizData.answer: He changed his mind and pulled out his hair as a symbol of renouncing worldly life.

quizData.question: What was the "elephant" that Bähubali needed to get off to achieve enlightenment?
Who helped Bähubali realize his ego was an obstacle?
Where is the gigantic statue of Bähubali located?
quizData.answer: On the hill of Vindhyagiri at Shravanbelgola.

quizData.question: What event led Bharat to realize the impermanence of his body and worldly possessions?
quizData.answer: A ring slipping off his finger, making him reflect on his appearance without ornaments.

quizData.question: What is the main moral of the story of Bharat and Bähubali?
quizData.answer: Ego and pride are destructive and must be overcome for enlightenment; humility is essential.

quizData.question: To whom did Rishabhadev give the city of Vinitä (Ayodhyä)?
To whom did Rishabhadev give the city of Taxashilä?
How long did Bähubali meditate standing motionless before his sisters came to him?
What title did Bharat achieve, becoming the first of the current time cycle?
According to Shvetämbar tradition, how did Bharat attain Keval-jnän?
quizData.answer: As a layperson, through reflection in his dressing room.

graphicsData.title: Rishabhadev Divides His Kingdom
graphicsData.description: King Rishabhadev, before his renunciation, divides his vast kingdom between his sons, giving Vinitä to Bharat and Taxashilä to Bähubali.
graphicsData.imageAlt: King Rishabhadev on his throne, with Bharat and Bähubali before him, map in background.

graphicsData.title: The Duel of Brothers
graphicsData.description: Bharat and Bähubali engage in a duel to decide superiority, avoiding a large-scale war.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Bharat and Bähubali in a dynamic combat pose.

graphicsData.title: Chakraratna's Failure
graphicsData.description: Bharat, in desperation, unleashes the Chakraratna against Bähubali, but it harmlessly circles Bähubali as it doesn't harm blood relatives.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Chakraratna spinning around an unharmed Bähubali, Bharat looking shocked.

graphicsData.title: Bähubali's Renunciation
graphicsData.description: About to strike Bharat, Bähubali has a flash of insight and instead pulls out his hair, renouncing the world on the battlefield.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Bähubali with hand raised, then changing to pull hair, battlefield in background.

graphicsData.title: Bähubali's Year-Long Meditation
graphicsData.description: Bähubali stands motionless in meditation for a year, so still that creepers grow around him, yet his ego prevents enlightenment.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Bähubali in deep meditation, covered in vines.

graphicsData.title: The Elephant of Ego
graphicsData.description: Brähmi and Sundari tell Bähubali he must "get off the elephant" of his ego to attain enlightenment.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Bähubali with a symbolic elephant of pride, Brähmi and Sundari speaking to him.

graphicsData.title: Bharat's Realization
graphicsData.description: Emperor Bharat, seeing his unadorned reflection, realizes the impermanence of worldly beauty and possessions, leading to his enlightenment.
graphicsData.imageAlt: Bharat looking in a mirror, seeing a plain self, with discarded jewels nearby.
